creator: netspam@shic.co.uk
text:
I've a few files which represent a draft for a very simple website - plain
XHTML/simple Javascript and a couple of jpeg photos. I can view these files
fine when I use a file://... URI - but run into a curious problem when I try to
access them via Apache on my local PC. I plop all the files into the htdocs
directory and point my browser (I've tried Firefox; IE6 and Lynx - all generate
a similar problem) at http://localhost/ as well as trying browsers on other PCs
- all my attempts exhibit the same problem.

While there is no problem with any of the XHTML pages (each of which is only a
few K) Whenever I point my browser at a photograph (One 124K and one 202K) I
seem to only correctly receive the first portion of each file... from
approximately two thirds of the way down each Jpeg is displayed corrupt. When I
do a binary comparison between a jpg downloaded from Apache and the original
file I find they are identical up-to an offset of 64K - thereafter I see
absolutely no similarity between the binary files - though the distribution of
byte values seems fairly uniform in both files and both files are of identical size.

Suspecting a problem with Apache configuration I uninstalled Apache 2.0.48,
deleted my configuration files and installed 2.0.53 (the current latest) - but
this had no effect.

Can anyone shed any light on this?  I find it difficult to believe I'm the first
to discover this - AFAIK I've done nothing even slightly out of the ordinary.

creator: chip@force-elite.com
text:
Try the commands listed here:
http://www.apache.org/dist/httpd/binaries/win32/#problems

Also, look at removing any firewall software (eg norton).  They all commonly cause this type of issue.

If the issue still persists, feel free to repoen the bug.

Thanks for the prompt and spot-on feedback.  You are right - this was a "known"
issue - though one for which I was previously unable to find the documentation.

Setting "EnableSendfile Off" was the key for me... I wonder, given that I was
using a fairly vanilla XP SP2 (with Symantec antivirus) and only the default
windows firewall... wouldn't it be a better idea if the default Win32
configuration was more conservative?  It would have saved me a lot of
frustration... My hunch is that those running Apache on Win32 are likely to be
doing this for smaller trafic volumes - hence a (potentially) slower but more
reliable default configuration would be extremely helpful.
creator: netspam@shic.co.uk

text:
IMHO "EnableSendfile Off" should be present and uncommented in the default
config files for all platforms, except for highperformance.conf.  I'll bring
this up again on the developer mailing list.  The subset of users who need a
little better performance can uncomment it and verify that the web server is
still operating properly.
